document.docAuthor: Penghai Qiao & Wen Qin & Huiqin Ma & Tongzuo Zhang
document.docTitle: Two new species of lithobiid centipedes and the first record of Lamyctes africanus Porath (Chilopoda: Lithobiomorpha) in China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new species of lithobiid centipedes and the first record of Lamyctes africanus Porath (Chilopoda: Lithobiomorpha) in China

paragraph.docTitle:
Two new species of lithobiid centipedes and the fi
rst record of
Lamyctes africanus Porath
(Chilopoda: Lithobiomorpha ) in China

subSection.paragraph:
Penghai Qiaoaıbıcı
Wen Qinbıcı
Huiqin Mad
and
Tongzuo Zhangb

aInstitute of Laboratory Animal Scienceı Guizhou University Of Traditional Chinese Medicineı Guiyangı China ; bQinghai Provincial Key Laboratory of Animal Ecological Genomicsı Northwest Institute of Plateau Biologyı Chinese Academy of Sciencesı Xiningı Qinghaiı China ; cNorthwest Institute of Plateau Biologyı Chinese Academy of Sciencesı University of the Chinese Academy of Sciencesı Beijingı China ; dScientific Research Officeı Hengshui Universityı Hengshuiı China

emphasis.paragraph:
ABSTRACT Two new species of lithobiid centipedes (
Hessebius prospinosa
sp. nov. and
Lithobius ( Ezembius ) maqinensis
sp. nov. ) and the first record of
Lamyctes africanus Porath
which are all femalesı suggest-
ing parthenogenesisı are described based on specimens from the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Keys for each of the Chinese species of
Hessebius
ı
Ezembius
and
Lamyctes
are presented. Phylogenetic analysis using a fragment (613 bp) of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (COI) indicates that (1)
Lithobius ( Ezembius )
maqinensis sp. nov. clades with L .
( E .) giganteus Sseliwanoffı
and (2) the specimens of
Lamyctes africanus Porath
from China clade with
L. africanus Porath
from other countries.

http://www.zoobank.org/
urn:lsid:zoobank.org:pub:
24364A2D-8D84-444D-9CFC-24336A211D2
B
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 22 July 2018
Accepted 6 April 2019
KEYWORDS
Hessebius
;
Ezembius
;
Lamyctes africanus
; Tibetan plateau
Introduction
The genus
Hessebius
was named by Verhoeff (1941) to include two Turkish speciesı
H. kosswigi Verhoeff
and
H. tauricus Verhoeff. The
genus is characterised chiefly by the massive expansion and projection of the dorsolateral ridge of the female gonopodı according to Zalesskaja (1978) .
Hessebius
is distributed mainly in the Palearctic region including Central Asia (Kirghizstanı Tajikistanı Turkmenistanı Kazakhstan )ı southern Russiaı the Middle East (Iranı Iraqı Armeniaı Syriaı Palestine )ı westward to Anatolia (Torosı including the South Sporades)ı Cyprus and north-east Africa (Egyptı Libya ) ( Zapparoli 2003 ). Until nowı five species of
Hessebius
have been recorded from China ( Ma et al. 2014 ; Qiao et al. 2018 ).
The centipede subgenus
Ezembius
was erected by Chamberlin (1919) as a monotypic genus to receive
Lithobius stejnegeri Bollman
from Bering Island ( Eason 1974 )ı and then was formally proposed as new and described in 1923 ( Chamberlin 1923 ).
Ezembius
is characterised by antennae with ca. 20 articlesı ocelli 1 + 4 – 1 + 20ı forcipular coxosternal teeth usually 2 + 2ı porodonts generally setiform but sometimes stoutı tergites generally © 2019 Informa UK Limitedı trading as Taylor & Francis Group
Published online
07 Jun 2019
without posterior triangular projectionsı tarsal articulation of legs 1 – 13 distinctı female gonopods with uni-ı bi- or tridentate clawı 2 + 2 – 3 + 3ı rarely 4 + 4 spurs ( Zapparoli and Edgecombe 2011 ). It accommodates a group of 58 species/subspecies known mostly from Asia but also from western North Americaı and spans a wide range of habitatsı from arctic and sub-arctic to tropical and sub-tropical forestsı to steppes and overgrazed stony areas of central Asiaı to Himalayan montane forestsı from the seashore up to 5500 m in the Himalayas ( Zapparoli and Edgecombe 2011 ). Altogetherı 19 species of
Lithobius ( Ezembius )
have been recorded from China ( Pei et al. 2018 ).
Currentlyı three genera of Henicopidae have been recorded in China :
Lamyctes Meinertı
Hedinobius Verhoeff
and cermatobius Haase ( Ma et al. 2014 ). The species of
Lamyctes
recorded from China include
Lamyctes pachypes Takakuwaı
distributed in Japanı Taiwanı China and Russiaı and
Lamyctes gracilipes Takakuwaı
distributed in Japanı Taiwan and China ( Ma et al. 2014 ).
Lamyctes
is mainly distributed in the southern hemisphere as well as Europe and Russia . Up to nowı three species of
Lamyctes
have been recorded in Russia ( Kurochkina 2007 ) and five species in Europe ( Enghoff et al. 2013 ). The distribution of the species
Lamyctes africanus (Porath)
includes Australiaı Île Saint-Paulı South Africaı Englandı Denmarkı Czech Republicı Germanyı France and the Hawaiian islands ( Enghoff et al. 2013 ; Dányi and Tuf 2016 ) ( Figure 1 ).
Figure 1. Distribution map of
Lamyctes africanus (Porath)
. Symbols denote countries. Octagon = Czech Republic; circle = England; rectangle = Denmark; triangle = Île Saint-Paul; pentagon = Hawaiian Islands; hexagon = South Africa; five-pointed star = China; maroon diamond = France; blue circle with dark core = Germany; circle with # symbol = Sydney.
Lamyctes africanus
is found in China on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. In this paperı we identify
L. africanus
from morphology and mitochondrial DNA using a fragment of the COI gene. We comment on the geographical origin of
L. africanus
.

subSection.paragraph: Specimens were all collected by handı preserved in 95% ethanol and deposited in the collections of the Northwest Institute of Plateau Biologyı Chinese Academy of Sciences (NWIPB). Morphological characters were examined using an SZ61 Olympus stereoscope. Specimens are numbered 1 to 12 and prefixed with the abbreviation of the locality. Terminology for external anatomy follows Bonato et al. (2010) . The abbreviations used are: a = anterior; C = coxa; D = dorsal; F = femur; m = median; p = posterior; P = prefemur; Sı SS = sterniteı sternites; Tı TT = tergiteı tergites; Ti = tibia; To = Tömösváry ’ s organ; Tr = trochanter; V = ventral; HY = Haiyan; MQ = Maqin; RGZ = Rikaze.

heading.emphasis: DNA extractionı polymerase chain reaction amplificationı and sequencing

subSection.paragraph:
Total DNA was extracted from a single leg removed from every specimen using the MicroElute Genomic DNA kit (Omega)ı after overnight incubation at 65°C. A continuous fragment (613 bp) of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (COI) was amplified by polymerase chain reaction (Mastercycler pro PCRı Eppendorff)ı with forward LCO-1490 (5 ’ - GGT CAA CAA ATC ATA AAG ATA TTG G- 3 ’ ) and HCO-2198 (5 ’ -TAA ACT TCA GGG TGA CCA AAA AAT CA- 3 ’ ) ( Folmer et al. 1994 ). The total PCR reaction volume was 39 μL containing 1 μL
5 – 60 ng
template DNA; 28 μL ddH2O; 5 μL 10× buffer (Takaraı Dalianı China ); 2.5 μL 0.5mm /L dNTPs (Takaraı Dalianı China ); 0.5 μL 5U/μL Taq polymerase (Takaraı Dalianı China ); 1 μL forward primer; and 1 μL reverse primer (synthesised by Sangon Biotech from Shanghai ). PCR was performed as follows: initial denaturing at 95°C for 10 min; followed by 35 cycles of 95°C for 30 sı 44°C for 30 sı and 72°C for 90 s; and a final extension at 72°C for 10 min. The PCR products were purified using a purification kit (DC28106 250 Prepsı Qiagenı Germany ). Sequencing reactions were carried out with PCR primers using the ABI Prism BigDye Terminator Cycle Sequencing Ready Reaction Kitı on an ABI 3730XL sequencer.

For the COI geneı sequences were aligned using ClustalX 2.0 ( Chenna et al. 2003 )ı and the aligned sequences were edited using BioEdit 7.0.9.0 ( Hall 1999 ). The alignment was evaluated for substitution saturation using DAMBE v. 5.3.74 ( Xia and Xie 2001 ; Xia and Lemey 2009 ). BLAST searches ( Altschul et al. 1997 )ı as implemented on the NCBI (National Center for Biotechnology Information) website (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/)ı were conducted to check for contamination. All of the sequences were deposited in the GenBank databaseı under accession numbers MF614147 ı MF614149 and MF614150 (
L. africanus
)ı MF045602 – MF045609 (
Hessebius prospinosa
sp. nov. and
Lithobius ( Ezembius ) maqinensis
sp. nov. ).

Substitution model selection was implemented in jModelTest 2.1.4 ( Darriba et al. 2012 )ı and the TPM3 + I + G model was selected for the data set by likelihood ratio tests either under the Akaike information criterion (AICı 12ı726.6267) or under the Bayesian information criterion (BICı 13ı088.9326). Topology was reconstructed under the TPM2uf+I + G model of nucleotide evolution in MrBayes. Bayesian inference (BI) was used to generate a phylogeny from the DNA sequences. BI was performed in MrBayes 3.2 ( Ronquist and Huelsenbeck 2003 ) with 3ı000ı000 generationsı sampling trees every 300 generations. Two independent runs each with four simultaneous Monte Carlo Markov chains (MCMC) were carried out. The first 25% of generations were discarded as ‘ burn-in ’ . The convergence of chains was confirmed until the average standard deviation of split frequency was below 0.01 (0.004534) and the potential scale reduction factor (PSRF) was close to 1.0 for all parameters. In the phylogenetic analysisı
Anopsobius neozelanicus Silvestri
was used as the outgroup.

Class CHILOPODA Latreille 1817 Order
LITHOBIOMORPHA Pocock 1895
Family
LITHOBIIDAE
Newport 1844
Subfamily
LITHOBIINAE
Newport 1844
Genus
Hessebius Verhoeffı 1941

subSubSection.paragraph: Haiyan Countyı Qinghai Provinceı Chinaı 36.92ı769°Nı 100.95ı264°Eı 7 December 2011ı 3044 m above sea levelı collected by Gonghua Lin.

Body length
14.2 – 15.8 mm
. Antennae with 20 antennomeres; 9 – 11 ocelli on each side arranged in 3 rows. Tömösváry ’ s organ ovalı almost equal in size to neighbouring ocelli ( Figure 2 (e)). Lateral margins of forcipular coxosternite slantingı anterior margin with 2 + 2 smallı blunt teeth and with thick porodonts. Tergites without triangular posterolateral processı a line of setae along posterior border of TT 8ı 10ı 12 and 14. Legs 14 and 15 thicker than anterior ones in both sexes. Coxal pores 4 – 6ı round to ovateı arranged in 1 row. Female gonopods with 2 elongated conical spursı the second article of the female gonopods having a massive process and a strong slightly curved spine. Terminal claw of the third article of female gonopods simpleı with a small triangular protuberance on basal ventral side. Male gonopods short and small.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 2.
Hessebius prospinosa
sp. nov. ı (a – c): paratypeı male: (a) habitusı dorsal viewı scale 1 mm; (b) forcipular coxosterniteı ventral viewı scale 500 μm; (c) posterior segments and gonopodsı ventral viewı scale 500 μm; (d – f) holotypeı female: (d) posterior segments and gonopodsı ventral viewı scale 500 μm; (e) ocelli and Tömösváry ’ s organı lateral viewı scale 250 μm; (f) right gonopodı lateral viewı scale 250 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Hessebius prospinosa
sp. nov. can be easily distinguished from the other
Hessebius
species that are known from China by the well-defined tarsal articulation on all legsı the strong spine on the massive expansion projecting from the second article of the female gonopodsı and the terminal claw of the female gonopods having a triangular protuberance on the inner aspect.
Based on holotype ( ♀ )ı body length 14.2 mm ; cephalic plate width 1.8 mmı length 1.6 mm .

Colour. Antennae and sternites brown-yellow. Coxosternite light yellow. Distal part of forcipule reddish brown. Legs pale yellowı except legs 14 and 15 reddish brownı claws yellowish brown. Tergites rufousı with headı first tergiteı fifth tergiteı and terminal tergite darker.

Antennae. Length 4.2 mmı 29.5% of body length with 20 + 20 articles. Basal article the same width as lengthı second one markedly longer than wideı following articles gradually shortening and taperingı distal article markedly longer than wideı up to 1.8 times as long as penultimate article. Abundant setae on the surface of antennaeı less so on the basal articlesı gradually increasing in density to about article 5ı then more or less constant.

Cephalic plate. Heart-shapedı smoothı posterior margin concave without median thickening; several symmetric setae scattered along the marginal ridge of the cephalic plate; a strong transverse suture dividing into 2 branchesı projection of lateral marginal discontinuous.

Ocelli. 1 + 4ı 4ı 2 oval to rounded ocelli on each side in 3 irregular rows. Posterior ocellus ovalı larger than the seriate ocelli; seriate ocelli moderately smallı approximately equal in size. All ocelli domedı translucentı usually darkly pigmented.
Tömösváry ’ s organ: ovateı almost the same size as the adjoining ocelliı some distance from the adjoining ocelliı situated on ventral side of cephalic pleurite ( Figure 2 (e)).

Coxosternites. Subtrapezoidal with narrowı very slightly recurved dental margin. Median diastema moderately wideı weakly V-shaped; anterior margin having the teeth developed as smallı blunt bulbs that are encircled by a narrow rimı sclerotisation is markedly greater on the bulbs than on the rims. Porodonts thick and longı lying posterolateral to the most lateral teeth on the ventral side of the coxosternite; some short and long setae scattered on the ventral side of coxosternite.

Tergites. Smoothı without wrinkles. Angles of posterolateral corners of tergites all rounded without triangular projections. T1 narrower than the cephalic plate and T3ı the cephalic plate almost the same width as T3. Posterior margin of TT 1ı 8 straightı continuous. Posterior marginal ridge of TT 3 and 5 concaveı continuous. Posterior margin of TT 7ı 9ı 11ı 12 and 14 slightly convexı T10 slightly concaveı all without ridge. All posterior angles generally roundedı without triangular projections. Lateral marginal ridge of all tergites continuous. Tiny setae scattered very sparsely over the surface. Short to long setae sparsely dispersed along lateral borders and posterior cornersı a band of setae on posterior border of TT 8ı 10ı 12ı 14.

Sternites. Trapeziformı posterior side narrower. SS 1 – 11 glabrousı about 8 – 10 comparatively short to long setae scattered sparsely on anterior and posterior lateral margin of each sternite. Three irregular lines of setae on posterior part of SS 10ı 11. Numerous minute seta surround the surface of SS 12 – 15 except that the middle is glabrous.

Legs. Clear tarsal articulation on all legs. Anterior and posterior accessory spines on legs 1 – 14ı no accessory spurs on leg 15. Anterior accessory spines long and slenderı about 0.5 times the length of principal clawı posterior one slightly strongerı about 0.3 times the length of principal claw. The anterior accessory spines form relatively large angles with the pretarsus. The posterior accessory spines form relatively small angles with the pretarsus. Leg pairs 14 and 15 longer and thicker than 1 – 13. Leg 15 longest of allı with tarsus 1 about 4.0 times longer than wide. Tarsus 2 about 60% length of tarsus 1. Abundant glandular pores on ventral surfaces of femurı tibia and tarsus of legs 14 and 15. Short to moderately long setae scattered over the surface of legs 1 – 13. Tarsi generally more setoseı few setae on legs 14 – 15. Tarsi 1 and 2 of legs 1 – 13 with combs of setae on ventral side. Legs ’ plectrotaxy: as in Table 1 .
Coxal pores. On the left 5664 and on the right 5665ı arranged in a singleı regular rowı circular or ovate. Coxal pore field set in a shallow grooveı with the fringe of coxal pore field distinct.

Female posterior segment. Sternite of female genital segment usually well chitinisedı wider than long; nearly glabrousı fringed with longer setae along the posterior lateral margin. Posterior margin of genital sternite deeply concave between the condyles of gonopodsı except for a smallı medianı approximately tongue-shaped bulge. Female gonopods divided into 3 articles as usual in Lithobiidaeı the first article moderately broadı bearing 28 – 30 short to moderately long setaeı arranged in 4 irregular rows. Seven short to long blunt spines along the dorsolateral ridge of the first article. The first article bearing 2 + 2 moderately longı bullet-shaped spursı inner spur slightly smaller and more anterior than the outer ( Figure 2 (d)). The second article with 5 moderately long setaeı arranged in 2 irregular rows. Nine short to long blunt spines along the dorsolateral ridge of the second article; the dorsal terminal part of the second article of the female gonopods strongly extending backwards and a robust slightly curved spine at the end of the massive projection ( Figure 2 (f)). Five moderately long setae on the surface of third article. Terminal claw simpleı slender and sharp ( Figure 2 (f))ı having moderately small protuberance on ventral-lateral side.

caption.paragraph:
Table 1.
Hessebius prospinosa
sp. nov. : legs ’ plectrotaxy; letters in brackets indicate variable spines.

subSubSection.paragraph: Male posterior segment. Posterior margin of the sternite of the genital segment quite deeply concave between gonopodsı no bulge medially. Gonopods short and smallı only a small hemisphere bulgeı with 4 long setae on surfaceı terminal surface of male gonopods slightly sclerotised.
Ocelli 1 + 4ı 4ı 2 or 1 + 4ı 3ı 1 or 1 + 3ı 3ı 2 on the cephalic plate. Coxal pores 5664ı 5555ı 5665 in female; 5565ı 5554ı 5555 in male.
Specimens were collected under railway stones.
The specific name refers to the strong spine on the massive expansion projecting from the second article of the female gonopods ( Figure 2 (f)).

paragraph.emphasis:
Key to species of the genus
Hessebius
in China

H. ruoergaiensis Qiaoı Qinı Maı Su and Zhang
4. Apical claw of female gonopods sharp and long with small triangular protuberance on the inner aspect; 2 – 4 setae on ventral surface of male gonopods .......................... 5

– Apical claw of female gonopods simple and broad; 6 – 8 setae on ventral surface of male gonopods..............................................
H. multiforaminis Peiı Maı Zapparoli and Zhu

5. A strong spine right on the massive expansion projecting on the second article of the female gonopods; 4 setae on ventral surface of male gonopods................................ ..............................................................................................................................
H. prospinosa
sp. nov.

– No strong spine right on the massive expansion projecting on the second article of the female gonopods; 4 setae on ventral surface of male gonopods................................ .....................................................................................

subSubSection.paragraph: Maqin Countyı located in south-eastern Qinghai Provinceı with plateau mountain habitat; 34.44544°Nı 100.26906°Eı altitude 3744 mı 7 October 2011ı collected by Weiping Li.

paragraph.materialsCitation: ♀ holotype ( MQ 4)ı 2 ♀ ( MQ 6ı MQ 7)ı 7 Ƌ ( MQ 1ı MQ3ı MQ5ı MQ8ı MQ9ı MQ10ı MQ 12) paratypes.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Lithobius ( Ezembius ) maqinensis
sp. nov. is morphologically close to L .
( E .) giganteus Sseliwanoffı
but can be readily distinguished by the following characters: 10 – 12 ocelli arranged in 3 rows (vs 6 – 10 arranged in 2 or 3 rows in
L. ( E. ) giganteus
)ı tarsal articulation not well defined on legs 1 – 13 (vs well defined)ı and apical claw of female gonopods simple with a small subtriangular tooth on the ventral side.
Based on holotype ( ♀ )ı body length 13.1 mm ; cephalic plate width 1.8 mmı length 1.9 mm .

Colour. Body yellow-brown with reddish hue. Dorsal plates with a median longitudinal dark stripeı venter coloured similarly to body. Antennae brown. Legs yellow. Distal part of forcipules and coxosternal teeth dark brown.

Antennae. Antennae composed of 20 + 20 articlesı antennal length 3.0 times width of head shieldı extending to anterior part of T3ı the first article longer than wideı the second slightly longer than wideı the third to seventh wider than longı then elongateı the ultimate about 2.5 times the length of the penultimate article.

Cephalic plate. ( Figure 3 (a)) Sub-cordateı smooth and glossyı nearly the same width as length. Four pairs of setae anterior to transverse suture with bilateral symmetry. Frontal marginal ridge with shallow anterior median furrow. Posterior margin slightly concave. Lateral margin discontinuousı broken about one-third the distance forward from the caudal edge.
Ocelli. ( Figure 3 (b)) 1 + 5ı 4ı 3 arranged in 3 rowsı the most posterior ocellus largestı the ocelli of the bottom row small.

Tömösváry ’ s organ.
Almost the same size as adjacent ocelliı well removed from the eye-patch area.

Forcipular coxosternite. ( Figure 3 (c)) Sub-trapezoidal; dental margin narrowı with 2 + 2 teethı setiform porodonts on small knobs; no lateral shoulders; median diastema cut deepı V-shaped; some scattered setae on the ventral side of coxosternite.

Tergites. ( Figure 3 (a)) smoothı never rugose; T1 posterolaterally narrower than anterolaterallyı trapeziformı narrower than T3 and the cephalic capsuleı T3 almost the same width as the cephalic capsule; posterior margin of TT 1ı 3ı 5ı 10ı 12ı 14 concaveı posterior margin of TT 7ı 8 straightı posterior marginal ridge of TT 1ı 3ı 5 continuous; posterior angles of all dorsal plates rounded without triangular projections; lateral marginal ridge of all tergites continuous; more setae on anterior and posterior angles of each tergite.

Sternites. Smoothı trapeziformı posteriorly narrow; 2 – 3 small setae on the lateral bordersı 1 – 2 comparatively long setae scattered sparsely on anterior and posterior lateral margin of each sternite. SS 11 – 15 more densely setose on anterior and posterior borders; posterior margins straight.

Legs. Legs 1 – 13 with unipartite tarsiı tarsi of legs 14 and 15 divided into 2 tarsomeres. Leg pairs 14 and 15 longer and thicker than 1 – 13. Leg 15 longest of allı tarsus 1 about 2.6 times longer than wideı tarsus 2 about 67% length of tarsus 1 on leg 15. Abundant glandular pores on ventral surfaces of femurı tibia and tarsus of legs 14 and 15. All legs with tarsal clawsı fairly longı curved ventrally. Legs 1 – 13 terminate in primary claws with anterior and posterior accessory spinesı anterior accessory spines long and slenderı about 0.33 times the length of principal clawı posterior one slightly strongerı about 0.3 times the length of principal claw. Anal legs with the tarsal claw singleı penultimate legs with the tarsal claw armed at base with posterior accessory spines. Legs ’ plectrotaxy: as in Table 2 .

caption.paragraph:
Figure 3.
Lithobius ( Ezembius ) maqinensis
sp. nov. ı (a – dı f) holotypeı female: (a) habitusı dorsal viewı scale 1 mm; (b) ocelli and Tömösváry ’ s organ (To)ı lateral viewı scale 250 µm; (c) forcipular segmentı ventral viewı scale 500 µm; (d) posterior segments and gonopodsı ventral viewı scale 500 µm; (f) right gonopodı dorsal-lateral viewı scale 250 µm; (e) paratypeı male: male gonopodı ventral viewı scale 500 µm.

Table 2. Plectrotaxy of
Lithobius ( Ezembius ) maqinensis
sp. nov. ı the holotype and paratypes. Letters in parentheses indicate variable spines.

subSubSection.paragraph: Coxal pores. ( Figure 3 (d)) Formula 6666ı round and uni-seriateı the most proximal pore on 15th coxae minute. Coxal pore field set in a relatively shallow grooveı the fringe of coxal pore field slightly distinct.

Female posterior segment. Posterior margin of genital sternite deeply concave between the condyles of gonopodsı except for a smallı median approximately fingerlike bulge. Female gonopod ( Figure 3 (d)): first article fairly broadı bearing about 24 long setae arranged in 4 irregular rows; 2 + 2 moderately smallı coniform spursı inner spur smallerı separated from one another by their own diameter at base. Second article with 10 medium to long setae. Third article with 4 long setae on its ventral surface. Terminal claw unidentateı curved with a small triangular protuberance on ventral side.

Male posterior segment. Male first genital sternite undivided longitudinallyı well chitinised. Posterior margin quite deeply concave between the gonopodsı no bulge medially; 32 short to medium setae scattered sparsely over its surface and at lateral margins ( Figure 3 (e)). Male gonopod: smallı undividedı oblique apicallyı with 2 setae ( Figure 3 (e)).

Body length
13.10 – 14.60 mm
; ocelli 9 – 11ı 1 + 4ı 3ı 1 or 1 + 4ı 3ı 2 or 1 + 5ı 4ı 2; coxal pores 4445ı 5466ı 6666 in femaleı 4444ı 4555ı 5554ı 5664ı 5665 in maleı ovate to roundı in each serious decreasing in size proximal as usual.
Collected under stones in alpine meadows composed mainly of Gramineae and Cyperaceae .
The new species is named from the type locality.

Lithobius ( Ezembius )

( E .) chekianus Chamberlin and Wang

( E .) bidens Takakuwa

subSubSection.paragraph:
15. No VpT on the anterior legsı apical claw of female gonopods with a small sub-
triangular tooth on the inner aspect L .
( E .) maqinensis
sp. nov. – VpT on the anterior legsı apical claw of female gonopods without a small subtrian- gular tooth on the inner aspect.............................................. L .
( E .) giganteus Sseliwanoffı
16. 6 ocelli on each side of cephalic plate.................................................................................... 17 – At least 7 ocelli on each side of cephalic plate ................................................................... 18 17. 14 th accessory spur absent........... ........... L . ( E .) anasulcifemoralis Maı Peiı Wu and Gai – 14 th accessory spur present........................ L .
( E .) gantoensis Takakuwa and Takashima
18. Tömösváry ’ s organ subequal in size to the largest ocellus L .
( E .) lineatus Takakuwa
– Tömösváry ’ s organ larger than the largest ocellus.............................. .............................. 19
19. At most 4 coxal pores.................................................. L . ( E .) zhui Peiı Maı Shiı Wu and Gai – 5 – 7 coxal pores.................................. .................................. L .
( E .) mandschreiensis Takakuwa

Subfamily
HENICOPINAE Pocock 1901
Genus
Lamyctes Meinertı 1868
Rikaze cityı Xizang ( Tibet ) Autonomous Regionı Chinaı 88.79ı833°Eı 29.20ı068°Nı elevation 3924 mı 5 September 2013ı collected by Jianping Suı Weiping Liı Jiarui Chen.

Lamyctes
with small body sizeı length from 6.5 mm to 10.2 mm . One prominent ocellus on each side of cephalic pleurite plate. 23 to 31ı most commonly 28 – 29 antennal articlesı with a few groups of short articles in pairsı markedly uneven in proximal part of antenna. Forcipular coxosternal teeth 2 + 2ı with a small lateral shoulder on each side of the lateral teeth. Porodonts spine-like; 12th tibiae with triangular distal spinose projectionsı 13th tibiae without distal spinose projections; 15th leg slenderı tarsal claw with anterior and posterior accessory claws. Female gonopods with 2 + 2 slender spurs. Gonopodal claw: terminal claw simpleı curved.
Note: Of 13 individuals collectedı RKZ7 and RKZ9 have smaller body sizeı about 4.8 mm (RKZ9) and 5.1 mm (RKZ7). Both have 28 antennal articles.

Body length 6.8 – 10.2 mmı cephalic plate
0.54 – 0.81 mm
longı
0.54 – 0.81 mm
wide. Leg 15 is about 23.4% (RKZ13) of the body length.

Colour in 95% ethanol. Basal antennal articles light yellow to orange-yellow. Tergites chestnut brown with deeper brown posterior and lateral bordersı 2 black lines extending medially from T1 to T14. Legs pale yellow except for deeper yellow tarsi. Pleural region pale grey; sternites pale yellow with dark hue. Distal part of forcipules brownı the remaining part of forcipulesı forcipular coxosternite and SS 14 and 15 pale orange-brown.

Antennae.
On the 10 specimens with complete antennaeı we counted 28 articles 6 timesı 29 articles twiceı and 26 articles twice; thereforeı the species typically has 28 articlesı 12% ( RKZ10 ) to 30% ( RKZ6 ) length of bodyı 1.5 ( RKZ11 ) to 3 ( RKZ 6 ) times length of head shield
. First 2 antennomeres much larger than succeedingı the length of the first antennae is almost equivalent to its widthı the second article conspicuously wider than lengthı then shortened.
Articles in pairs include articles 3 – 4ı 6 – 7ı 9 – 10 and 12 – 13ı conspicuously on RKZ3 and RKZ13
. Articles in distal part of antenna sub-moniliformı mostly of about equal length and width. Terminal article typically about 2.5 times the length of penultimate article. Antennal setation: abundant setae on antennal surfaceı but fewer setae on ventral and dorsal side in basal articlesı gradual increase in density of setae from first to seventh articleı then more or less constant.

Cephalic plate. With black markings not only around the pale eyesı but in several cases the dark colour is present on the major part of the cephalic shieldı forming ‘ conspicuous black markings around the pale eyes (similar to a “ raccoon mask ” ) ’ ı as described by
Enghoff et al. ( 2013
ı p. 5). Smoothı convexı heart-shapedı slightly wider than longı approximately the same width as T3. Frontal margin with conspicuous median notch ( Figure 4 (a))ı lacking median furrow; projection of lateral margin discontinuous. Border of equal width posteromedially and posterolaterallyı posterior margin slightly convex. Tiny setae inserted in pores scattered very sparsely over the surface; short to long setae scattered along the marginal ridge.
Ocelli. All females have 1 bulging large lavender ocellus on each side.

Forcipular coxosternite. Subtriangular. Dental margin narrow and curvedı about 28% of the maximum width of coxosterniteı with 2 + 2 large pointed teeth and spine-like porodontı porodont just inside anterolateral corner of dental marginı separated from outer tooth by a greater distance than that separating the two teeth from each other ( Figure 4 (b)). Median diastema moderately deepı V-shaped. Some small setae scattered on ventral aspect of coxosternite. Forcipular tarsungulum: pretarsal section of approximately equal length to tarsal section. There are more setae on dorsal side of tarsal part of tarsungulumı tibia and femur than on ventral ( Figure 4 (b)). Pleurites of forcipular segment connected ventrallyı forming a continuous band between forcupular coxosternite and sternite of first leg-bearing segment.

Tergites. Moderately smoothı without wrinklesı backside hunched. T1 posterolaterally narrower than anterolaterallyı generally trapeziformı slightly narower than the width of head and T3. Cephalic plate of same width as T3. Posterior margin of T1 sinuateı posterior margin of TT 3 and 5 slightly concaveı posterior margin of TT 8ı 10ı 12 and 14 moderately concaveı posterior margins of short tergites subtransverseı with broadly rounded posterior angles. Lateral marginal ridge of all tergites continuous. TT 1ı 3ı 5 and 8 bordered posteriorlyı TT 10ı 12ı 14 bordered laterally only or with short extent of border posterolaterally. All tergites bordered laterally. Tergite of intermediate segments with concave posterior margin. Posterolateral corners of tergites all rounded. Tiny setae scattered on the anteriorı posterior angles of each tergite.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 4.
Lamyctes africanus (Porath)
ı (aıe) RKZ11ı female: (a) dorsal viewı scale 1 mm; (e) ventral view of posterior segments and gonopodsı scale 100 µm; (b) RKZ3ı female: forcipular segmentı ventral viewı scale bar 500 µm; (c) RKZ11ı female: leg 12 in dorsal lateral viewı scale 500 μm; (d) RKZ13ı female: leg 15 in dorsal lateral viewı scale 500 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Sternites. Trapeziformı smooth. Short to long setae fringe along anterior and posterior margin.

Legs. No articulations on tarsus of legs 1 – 12ı strong articulations defined on legs 13 – 15. Claws on all legsı moderately longı curved ventrally. Anterior and posterior accessory claws on all legsı about half the length of main clawı the anterior ones moderately long and slenderı forming moderately larger angles with tarsal claws and posterior ones slightly strongı forming moderately smaller angles with tarsal claws. Distal spinose projection present on tibia of legs 1 – 12 and absent on tibia of legs 13 – 15. Leg 12: the triangular distal spinose projection is visible on the 12th tibiae of all adult females ( Figure 3 (d)). Leg 15: length of each of the three distal articles of the 15th leg in comparison with their own diameter: 15th tibiae: 0.66 mm / 0.15 mm – 0.68 mm / 0.14 mm = 4.3 x – 4.9 x; 15th tarsus 1:
0.55 – 0.59 mm
/ 0.07 mm = 7.9 x – 8.4 x; 15th tarsus 2:
0.6 – 0.62 mm
/ 0.06 mm = 10 x – 10.3 x.

Coxal pores. On legs 12 – 15ı roundı inner pores sometimes smaller; in all specimens 2222/2222 except one specimenı RKZ13 2332/2332; short to moderately long setae sparsely scattered over the surface.

Female posterior segment. S 15 in female with transverse posteromedian margin. Sternite of first genital segment with concave posteromedian margin except for a small median bulge. Setae scattered sparsely over its surface and at lateral margins. Female gonopods ( Figure 4 (e)) with 2 + 2 slender spursı proximal mesal spur inserted considerably more anteriorly than lateral spur. Basal article bearing 20 to 22 setaeı second article with 3 setaeı third article with 2 or 4 setae ( Figure 4 (e)). Claw simpleı curved.
The 13 specimens were all collected from broken stones on a slope along the side of the 318 National Roadı surrounding by leguminous plants and shrubs.

heading.emphasis:
Key to Chinese species of
Lamyctes

paragraph.keyLead: – Coxosternite with teeth 2 + 2ı tibial projections on the 1st to 12th legs ................... 2

2. Frontal margin of cephalic capsule with strong median notchı lacking median furrow .............................................................................................................................
L. gracilipes Takakuwa

subSection.paragraph: Alignment of the PCR fragment sequences from COI showed that in the 613 bp there were 271 variable sites and 258 parsimony-informative characters. The base composition of the fragments showed a strong bias of A + T (28.9 + 32.9). The results of the substitution saturation test showed that the index of substitution saturation 0.2472 ( Iss ) was significantly lower than the critical value of the index of substitution saturation 0.7285 ( Iss.c ).

Calculation of the distances (Appendix Table A2 ) between species showed that they ranged from 15.1% (
Lamyctes africanus
/
L.coeculus (Brölemann)
to 26.4% (
Lithobius ( Lithobius )
for fi catus
(Linnaeus)/
Lamyctes inermipes Silvestri
) with an average genetic distance of 19.5%. Intraspecific distances varied within
Lamyctes emarginatus
( Newport ) (8.8%)ı
Lamyctes coeculus (Brölemann)
(0.02%)ı
Lithobius
( E .) maqinensis
sp. nov. (0.02%)ı and
Lamyctes . africanus
(5.9%). The mean distance was 19.2% (max. 21.9% between
Lithobius ( Ezembius ) maqinensis
sp. nov. and
Bothropolys xanti Wood
) in the family Lithobiidae and 17.3% (max. 22.3%
Lamyctes inermipes Silvestri
/
Paralamyctes ( Paralamyctes ) harrisi Archey
) in Henicopidae .

BI analysis ( Figure 5 ) reveals that Lithobiomorpha shows a split between Lithobiidae and Henicopidae with posterior probabilities of 92.78%ı the latter including a monophyletic Henicopini (
Lamyctes + Henicops
Newport +
Paralamyctes Pocock
).
Lamyctes coeculus (Brölemann)
ı
Lamyctes africanus (Porath)
group and
Lamyctes emarginatus Silvestri
were recovered as monophyletic clades with posterior probabilities exceeding 70%. The monophyly of
Paralamyctes
is also supported by the COI dataı with posterior probabilities of 99.93%.

Hessebius prospinosa
sp. nov. was placed in the basal position as the sister to the clade
Lithobius ( Ezembius ) maqinensis
sp. nov. ı with posterior probability 98.77%.
Lamyctes
is not a monophyletic groupı as it contains
Henicops maculatus
Newport .

Henicops maculatus
ı
L. hellyeri Edgecombe and Giribetı
L. inermipes
and the
Lamyctes ‘africanus’
specimen from Cape Townı South Africaı form distinct lines.

The sequences of RKZ 2ı 4 from China are identical to the
Lamyctes africanus
from Germany and Australiaı differing in two base pairs from RKZ 5 and the Danish
L. africanus
specimen.
Clear intraspecific distances are lowı from 0.02% to 8.8%. This allows us to identify species because interspecific distances are remarkably higher than intraspecific distances.

The clade of the new species
Lithobius ( Ezembius ) maqinensi
sp. nov. constitutes a sister group with the clade of
Hessebius prospinosa
sp. nov. ı perhaps due to geographic proximity.
Lithobius
( E .) maqinensi
sp. nov. and
H. prospinosa
sp. nov. ı with weak migration capacityı have the same ancestors and diverge gradually as mutations accumulate. Hessbius is not a taxon at the generic level but rather a subgenus of
Lithobius
ı based on the partial COI geneı although we do not know what factors (genetic or environmental) are associated with the phenotype of projection of the dorsolateral ridge of the female gonopod.

The L . ‘emarginatus’ specimenı whose voucher is labelled AM KS 57960ı from a garden in Sydneyı Australiaı branching within
L. africanus
ı is confirmed genetically as
L. africanus
ı showing a 100% identity with our Chinese
L. africanus
and German
L. africanus
. It may have been an identification error in terms of morphologyı because one often overlooks the particularly slender 15th legs and the tibial projection on the 12th legs ( Enghoff et al. 2013 ) in
L. africanus
.

caption.paragraph: Figure 5. Bayesian tree for the 38 sequences based on COI sequences. The Bayesian posterior probabilities from Bayesian analyses are presented above the main branches. The scale bar represents substitutions per site. Country of origin given in square brackets: AU = Australia; CH = China; GE = Germany; DK = Denmark; SA = South Africa.

subSection.paragraph:
The L . ‘africanus’ ı whose voucher is labelled DNA 100287 ı from South Africa also forms a distinct branchı indicating a possible new speciesı and did not prove to belong to
L. africanus
. The divergence (15.4%) between AF334314.1 L . ‘africanus’ and the
L. africanus
group is deep. In morphologyı ‘ With reservation for characters which could not be observedı it is not possible to distinguish these specimens morphologically from what we call L. africanus’ (
Enghoff et al. 2013
ı p. 14).

According to Eason (1996)ı
L. africanus
is a junior synonym of
L. emarginatus
. Howeverı not only do the two species have morphological differences (details in Enghoff et al. 2013 )ı but the distance between them is great (25.0%). They pertain to two different valid species.

COI is appropriate for DNA barcoding for
Lamyctes
to identify a particular species in this studyı as COI variations between species of
Lamyctes
averaged 14.2%ı whereas variation within species of
Lamyctes
averaged 4.96%. The distance within species is dramatically smaller than that between species; thusı this marker can enable identifications where traditional methods are not applicable – perhaps most importantly when the two species have similar appearances such as
L. emarginatus
and
L.africanus
ı and subtle morphological differences.

The low numbers of variable sites in
L. africanus
show clearly that these populations from different countries still have not yet produced high genetic differentiation. These populations may not have been isolated for a long time; henceı not many mutations have accumulated.

The wide distribution of
L. africanus
is owed to its synanthropy and parthenogenesis. Its origin was probably in Australia where males have been recorded and illustrated ( Edgecombe et al. 2002 ). In additionı the family Henicopidae is distributed on all continents except Antarcticaı but is most characteristic of the southern temperate regionsı where it largely replaces
Lithobiidae ( Eason 1992 )
. We suppose that the males of
L. africanus
on Île Saint-Paulı a remote island in the Indian Oceanı may have been introduced from Australia .

We express our great gratitude to the centipede specialist Ivan Handrián Tuf and Joseph DeSistoı Editor Andrew Polaszekı Professor Paul Marek and Thomas Wesener for their great help with the manuscript.
No potential conflict of interest was reported by the authors.

This work was supported by the the Strategic Priority Research Program of the Chinese Academy of Sciences [XDA2002030302]; National Key R&D Program of China [2017YFC0506405]; The Natural Science Foundation of China programme [31572239]; the Construction Fund for Qinghai Key Laboratories [2017-ZJ-Y23]; and Qinghai Key R&D and Transformation Program [2019-SF-150].
